we're gonna talk about today my name is

there are a lot of devices out there

so here at matte box our goal is to
provide the tools and the structures and

contextualize all of this spatial data
as you collect it and add context to it
over time and I like to think about
asset tracking as a three-part cycle
here the most important piece is that
first piece without collecting the data
in the first place you don't have
anything to work with so the first step
is having some sort of data collection
device whether it's a mobile phone
running an application with a is pulling
data from the GPS sensor or some kind of
IOT sensor that you're attaching to your
shipping container or your locomotive
that has a GPS sensor so you're
collecting that location data and
sending it up to the server so that's
the first piece once that did is
collected and depending on the richness
of that client device you're gonna have
an analysis phase where you're adding
context to that data and we're gonna

we move on but that's where you add
value to that data if it's just a
location maybe you're gonna add some
other stuff to it then you feed that
into your business process you use it to
make better decisions happier customers
and ideally hopefully that will lead to
more users more downloads more activity
which will then produce more data and so
the beautiful thing about this is that
it's a positive feedback loop and as we
know that those are hard to come by it's
a thing where the more you do it the
better things get so the more data you
collect the more analysis you can do the
better your business does which then
leads to more data so it's a win-win and
each of these three phases lines up with
a different set of api's and tools that
we provide at mapbox so Matlock's is a
location services company we provide a
whole variety of different types of
api's and services that you can use to
make sense of your geographic data so
during that initial collection phase
maybe we've got a mobile phone that
we're using to collect the current
position of a driver in that case we
might be using the directions or matrix
api's to calculate ETA s so how long
it's going to take for the driver to get
to their destination maybe we want to
get that geometry of that route and put

we also might be doing some geocoding
that's where you're converting from a
text string into a latitude and
longitude or vice versa
so we might be using that to allow our
driver to search for a location and put
that on the map or to assign a place
label like where is the driver right now
what's the name of that place
so that would fall under geocoding the
border between the collection and
analysis phases can sometimes be blurry
it's not always cut and dry because some
things you can you'll have to decide
whether you want to do it on the device
or in the cloud but either way mat
matching usually would happen on that
server-side piece because you might have
a messy GPS coordinate that comes out of
your sensor and you want to snap it to
the nearest road network segment so it
looks nice on the map so we use the mat
matching API for that and then at the
end of the day what Matt box is most
known for is our Maps API that allows
you to build and deploy beautiful
performant customisable Maps that work
on any device so all of the data that
we're collecting here all of that that
XS context that we're providing here
it's all going to end up on a map so we
